text: This is jupyter notebook with some python code and markdown text. These can also be included directly into a quarto website.

title: Milestone 1
text:
Import Libraries

import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np

title: Milestone 1
text:
Make Plots
We shall now make a simple plot. Note that by using the quarto option #| code-fold: true , we can hide the code that is used to make the plot and allow it to be expanded as shown below.


Code
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import numpy as np
x = np.linspace(0, 2, 100)  # Sample data.

plt.figure()
plt.plot(x, x, label='linear')  # Plot some data on the (implicit) axes.
plt.plot(x, x**2, label='quadratic')  # etc.
plt.plot(x, x**3, label='cubic')
plt.xlabel('x')
plt.ylabel('y')
plt.title("Simple Plot")
plt.legend()
plt.show()

title: Automatic model discovery using symbolic regression (I/II)
text:
Declare commands / Hide content
Using
::: hidden
$$
\DeclareMathOperator*{\argmin}{arg\,min}
$$
:::
we can define a latex operator if needed.

\[
\DeclareMathOperator*{\argmin}{arg\,min}
\]

\[\begin{align*}
  & \hat{\mathbf{\xi}} = \argmin_{\mathbf{\xi}} || \mathbf{U}_t - \mathbf{\Theta}(\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{Q}) \xi ||^2_2 + \epsilon \; \kappa \left( \mathbf{\Theta}(\mathbf{U}, \mathbf{Q})  \right) ||\mathbf{\xi}||_0 \\
  & \epsilon : \text{regularization parameter} \\
  & \kappa :  \text{condition number of } \mathbf{\Theta} \\
  & ||\mathbf{\xi}||_0 : \text{penalty to discourage overfitting}
\end{align*}\]

title: 2025-05-13: Meeting 1
text:
We discussed:

Motivation behind modeling of the thermo-hydrological behaviour

improve GHE Design Decisions
improve thermal conductivity -> more efficient heat transfer -> less circulations needed
less circulation -> less pump work (less energy consumption) -> higher efficiency
also reduced size of the system -> less (expensive) area needed (shallow GHE)

Possible research directions:

atmospheric and rainfall models/predicitons are publicly available
we can use these models to and make predictions about long-term behaviour of the GHE
GHE are usually build for long time frames (~30 years?) -> this way we can take climate change into account
another idea: deep GHE can be used as mechanically stabilizing the soil (?)
further coupling the MPINN with mechanical behaviour
another idea: GSHP circulation calculations?
another idea: looking at the thermodynamical cycle of the GSHP

Next Steps:

Go through PINN Tutorial (online tutorial, MBD lecture slides)
https://mbd_lectures.pages.rwth-aachen.de/cf4dt/content/exercises/exercise_assignment_7.html
set up easy problem (heat equation?) to get a hang on PINNs
set up PINN for water infiltration
set up PINN for thermal behaviour
then coupling (MPINN)

Further Info:

add papers you read to bibligraphy

title: Run a solver and plot data
text:
The beauty is that we can simply switch the style to generate the right plot for the occasion!
# import matplotlib
# styles can be found here https://matplotlib.org/stable/gallery/style_sheets/style_sheets_reference.html
# print(matplotlib.style.available)
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import sample_code as code
# plt.style.use('seaborn-v0_8-talk')
from matplotlibstyle import *

fig, ax = plt.subplots(2, constrained_layout=True)
x, y = code.solver()
code.plot(ax[0], x, y, label='sin(x)')
code.plot(ax[0], x, 2*y, label='2*sin(x)')
code.plot(ax[1], x, 3*y, label='3*sin(x)')
ax[0].legend()
ax[1].legend()
plt.show()







Figure 1: Caption

title: Eike Bergen - Multi-physics Informed Neural Networks
text:
Abstract
Both Green Infrastructure and Ground Source Heat Exchangers provide opportunities to significantly improve the resilience and sustainability of our built environment. Potential of utilising green infrastructure as a medium for ground heat exchange has been investigated by Yildiz and Stirling (2022) by conducting heat injection tests in a heavily-instrumented bespoke field setup. In order to upscale these findings to many different green infrastructure components with various ground source heat pump configurations, advanced simulation techniques can be utilised. Multiphysics-Informed Neural Networks (Wang et al. (2023)) provide a great opportunity here.

title: Eike Bergen - Multi-physics Informed Neural Networks
text:
Study material

Seungchul Lee - Physics-informed Neural Networks, accessed on 2025-05-14

title: Eike Bergen - Multi-physics Informed Neural Networks

Yildiz, Anil; Stirling, Ross (2020). PLEXUS @ NGIF - Field and laboratory measurements. Newcastle University. Collection. doi: 10.25405/data.ncl.c.5088419.v1

References


Bandai, T., Ghezzehei, T.A., 2021. Physics‐informed neural networks with monotonicity constraints for richardson‐richards equation: Estimation of constitutive relationships and soil water flux density from volumetric water content measurements. Water Resources Research 57. https://doi.org/10.1029/2020wr027642


Ng, C.W.W., Zhou, Q., Zhang, Q., 2025. A novel surrogate model for hydro-mechanical coupling in unsaturated soil with incomplete physical constraints. Computers and Geotechnics 180, 107091. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.compgeo.2025.107091


Wang, Y., Shi, L., Hu, X., Song, W., Wang, L., 2023. Multiphysics‐informed neural networks for coupled soil hydrothermal modeling. Water Resources Research 59. https://doi.org/10.1029/2022wr031960


Yildiz, A., Stirling, R.A., 2022. Ground heat exchange potential of green infrastructure. Geothermics 101, 102351. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.geothermics.2022.102351


Yildiz, A., Stirling, R.A., 2021. Thermo-hydrological behaviour of green infrastructure: A comparative field and laboratory study. Geomechanics for Energy and the Environment 25, 100219. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.gete.2020.100219
